div.head: Preface
div.p: The application of enzymes or whole cells (fermentatively active or resting; microbial, plant, or animal) to carry out selective transformations of commercial importance is the central theme of industrial biocatalysis. Traditionally, biocatalysis has been in the domain of the life scientist or biochemical engineer. However, recent advances in this field have enabled biocatalytic processes to compete head on with, and in some cases outperform, conventional chemical processing. Chemo-biocatalytic systems are being developed thereby combining the most attractive features of biocatalysts, namely high specificity, with those of chemical catalysts, such as high reactivities and wide substrate specificities. Hence, synthetic chemists and chemical engineers are now beginning to use biocatalysts as highly selective reagents in chemical synthesis and processing.

This book is about biocatalysts and their past, present, and potential applications in the food, pharmaceutical, and chemical industries. The concept of the book did not emanate from a meeting. Rather, it is a compilation of selected examples where biocatalysis either has already made a significant impact in the aforementioned industries, or has the potential to make a substantial contribution. I have been fortunate to have assembled contributions from world-class researchers in the field of biocatalysis. Their timely contributions are sincerely appreciated.

The book mainly deals with enzymes, but whole resting cells and catalytic antibodies are also discussed. It is aimed at a reader who has some background in chemistry and who has a need to understand how biocatalysts are used, where they have been employed, and what the future of biocatalysis is likely to be. The book is divided into four sections. The first functions as background material for the rest of the text, including a historical overview of biocatalysis prior to 1950. The second section deals with examples of biocatalytic systems that have no direct competition from vii chemical catalysts. For the most part such examples have arisen from the inability of chemical catalysts to catalyze a desired transformation, either due to a lack in selectivity or high potential for causing unacceptable health hazards. Such examples have been typically in the food industry, most notably carbohydrate modification. However, the area of biopolymer synthesis and modification has also become increasingly important for the development of polymeric drugs, peptides and hormones, novel carbohydrate derivatives, lignin-derived materials, and biopulping. Key aspects of the third section include the use of biocatalysts in areas conventionally believed to be restricted to chemical processing; particularly, the application of enzymes in organic solvents both in general terms and with specific examples including stereoselective biotransformations, modification of commercially important fats, and the use of enzymes in supercritical fluids. The final section of this book deals with several key future biocatalytic developments. This includes the application of protein-stabilizing techniques to increase the lifetime of biocatalysts and thereby enhance productivities, the use of site-directed mutagenesis to alter systematically the catalytic properties of enzymes to make them more suitable as catalysts for selected transformations, the development of antibodies with high specificity coupled with catalytic activity, and the use of enzyme-containing reactors for selective bioseparations.

In each chapter, basic information is given to familiarize the general reader with the specific topic. In each case, the author(s) have speculated on the future applications of the specific technology or process. It is hoped that the reader will learn enough from the specific examples provided in the book to consider applying biocatalysts to fit their own catalytic requirements. Finally, the gracious support of my wife, Vera, is affectionately acknowledged.
